docs.lead_paragraph: Edward J. Leary, whose lawyers contend he was driven by a mix of antidepressant and anti-anxiety drugs when he carried firebombs onto two Manhattan subway trains in 1994, forged his psychiatrist's signature on at least two prescriptions, a detective testified yesterday. Detective Michael Sapraicone said he showed Dr. John Weihs, a psychiatrist Mr. Leary found through an ad in The Village Voice, five of the prescriptions he supposedly wrote for the defendant. The psychiatrist told the detective that at least two for the anti-anxiety drug, Buspar, dated September and November 1994, were forgeries, Detective Sapraicone testified.

docs.lead_paragraph: They called it the failure of success. As medical scientists got better and better at treating people with fatal diseases -- but not curing them -- the nation would be burdened with an accumulation of elderly people who were living longer and longer but were crippled with pain and riddled with disabilities. It was a notion that called into question what medicine had wrought. But, to nearly everyone's surprise, the predicted pandemic of pain and disability has not materialized. Instead, new information, some not yet published, on studies involving people at all socioeconomic levels show that not only are Americans living longer, but they are developing less chronic disease and disability. And the reasons may have as much to do with changing social circumstances, including events that occur in the first few decades of life, as they have to do with medical advances in treating diseases.

headline.main: New Era of Robust Elderly Belies Fears of Scientists

docs.lead_paragraph: Nestled since 1909 in the sheltering hills of western Massachusetts, the Berkshire School has earned a reputation as one of the more nurturing private secondary schools in New England. Then last month, a substance thought to be the illegal hallucinogen colloquially known as LSD shattered the school's tranquility, compelling students and faculty members alike to weigh the larger costs of drug abuse. A pair of Berkshire students were rumored to have smuggled in as many as 200 doses and sold them for $5 to $7 a "hit" to other students, infusing a Saturday night with disorientation and panic.

headline.main: Drug Incident Shakes a School Campus

docs.lead_paragraph: From among the marijuana banana bread and magic brownies, the cannabis "merry pills" and the eight grades of loose marijuana listed on the cheery wall menu like ice cream flavors, Gypsy Calabrese chose a bag of the top-grade Asian "Quad-A." "After I leave here," Mr. Calabrese said as he packed a pipe with the greenish crumbles, "I won't feel my pain."

headline.main: Marijuana Club Helps Those in Pain

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN Hippocrates knew that a blow to the head can leave bruises on the mind. By studying the effects of brain injuries, he demonstrated that the mind is centered not in the heart, as some romantics believed, but right behind the eyes. It has taken centuries and the invention of brain-scanning to show that the connection between mind and brain is a two-way street: changing the mind, oddly enough, can alter the physical substance of the brain. But for all the scientific evidence, the interaction between what we think of as the material brain and the ethereal mind remains a source of wonder.

headline.main: Yes, There Is Such a Thing As Mind Over Matter

docs.lead_paragraph: Discovery of an important biochemical difference in the brains of smokers suggests a new way, independent of nicotine, in which smoking may become addictive. The discovery concerns an enzyme that breaks down dopamine, a pleasure-enhancing chemical in the brain. Using a technique for imaging the living brain, reseachers at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., have found that the enzyme is 40 percent less active in smokers, suggesting that dopamine levels would presumably be somewhat higher.

headline.main: Brain Chemical Said to Play Role in Cigarette Addiction
